articles.headline: The Tax-Break Bonanza Inside the Economic Rescue Package
articles.snippet: As small businesses and individuals struggle to obtain federal aid, the wealthiest are poised to reap tens of billions of dollars in tax savings.
articles.abstract: As small businesses and individuals struggle to obtain federal aid, the wealthiest are poised to reap tens of billions of dollars in tax savings.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the federal government dispenses trillions of dollars to save the economy, small businesses and out-of-work individuals are jostling to grab small slices of aid before the funds run out.
articles.byline: By Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: Trump Speech to Bring 1,000 West Point Cadets Back to Campus
articles.snippet: The president’s off-again, on-again speech in June will bring back cadets who had scattered across the country to help counter the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: The president’s off-again, on-again speech in June will bring back cadets who had scattered across the country to help counter the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Trump, who adores the pomp and precision of military ceremonies, this was the year he would finally get one of the special perks of being president — delivering the commencement address at West Point, the only service academy where he has not spoken.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Annie Karni

articles.headline: Pressured by China, E.U. Softens Report on Covid-19 Disinformation
articles.snippet: A revised report shows how Beijing reacts swiftly and effectively to tamp down Western criticism of its pandemic response.
articles.abstract: A revised report shows how Beijing reacts swiftly and effectively to tamp down Western criticism of its pandemic response.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Bowing to heavy pressure from Beijing, European Union officials softened their criticism of China this week in a report documenting how governments push disinformation about the coronavirus pandemic, according to documents, emails and interviews.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Zoom’s Biggest Rivals Are Coming for It
articles.snippet: Facebook, Google and other behemoths are training their sights on Silicon Valley’s company of the moment.
articles.abstract: Facebook, Google and other behemoths are training their sights on Silicon Valley’s company of the moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As people turned in droves to the video chatting app Zoom in recent weeks, the buzz caught Facebook’s attention. Inside the social network, that immediately set off a scramble.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: Businesses Tiptoe Into a World of Masks, Gloves and Wary Customers
articles.snippet: Some states have taken tentative steps toward reopening businesses shuttered by the coronavirus. In Georgia, it meant a few residents were out getting haircuts and their tongues pierced.
articles.abstract: Some states have taken tentative steps toward reopening businesses shuttered by the coronavirus. In Georgia, it meant a few residents were out getting haircuts and their tongues pierced.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Weeks after a deadly virus reordered daily life in America, shuttering most businesses and forcing most people indoors, three states on Friday took tentative steps toward something resembling normalcy. But across Georgia, Alaska and Oklahoma, it was anything but business as usual.
articles.byline: By Rick Rojas and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: How to Ask a College for More Financial Aid
articles.snippet: It’s an admissions season unlike any other, with uncertainty for students and their families — and the colleges that want to get them in the door.
articles.abstract: It’s an admissions season unlike any other, with uncertainty for students and their families — and the colleges that want to get them in the door.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is rarely easy to summon the will to ask for help, especially if you’re seeking more financial aid from what you believe to be your first-choice college.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Reopening Has Begun. No One Is Sure What Happens Next.
articles.snippet: The heated debate over when to restart the economy has obscured an issue that could prove just as thorny: How to do it.
articles.abstract: The heated debate over when to restart the economy has obscured an issue that could prove just as thorny: How to do it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy shut down almost overnight. It won’t start back up that way.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman

articles.headline: A Candidate in Isolation: Inside Joe Biden’s Cloistered Campaign
articles.snippet: Walled off from voters in a distinctive kind of lockdown, Mr. Biden has developed a routine, of sorts, as he seeks the presidency from his basement.
articles.abstract: Walled off from voters in a distinctive kind of lockdown, Mr. Biden has developed a routine, of sorts, as he seeks the presidency from his basement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. usually rises before 8 a.m. at his home in Wilmington, Del., and starts his day with a workout in an upstairs gym that contains a Peloton bike, weights and a treadmill. He often enjoys a protein shake for breakfast and puts on a suit or blazer much of the time. In the evenings, he and his wife, Jill, sit down together for dinner, a ritual that was absent for much of the last frenzied year on the campaign trail.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns, Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: In a Crowded City, Leaders Struggle to Separate the Sick From the Well
articles.snippet: Chelsea, Mass., has an infection rate higher than any other community in the state. With families in cramped housing, it is difficult to contain the spread.
articles.abstract: Chelsea, Mass., has an infection rate higher than any other community in the state. With families in cramped housing, it is difficult to contain the spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHELSEA, Mass. — Paul Nowicki, the director of operations for the housing authority in this small, crowded immigrant city, walked the halls of the Buckley Apartments last week in a plastic face shield and white gown, trying to stop an invisible predator.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Prescriptions Surged as Trump Praised Drugs in Coronavirus Fight
articles.snippet: Prescriptions for two antimalarial drugs jumped by 46 times the average when the president promoted them on TV. There’s no proof they work against Covid-19.
articles.abstract: Prescriptions for two antimalarial drugs jumped by 46 times the average when the president promoted them on TV. There’s no proof they work against Covid-19.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was at a midday briefing last month that President Trump first used the White House telecast to promote two antimalarial drugs in the fight against the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Ellen Gabler and Michael H. Keller

articles.headline: Testing Remains Scarce as Governors Weigh Reopening States
articles.snippet: In both red and blue states, governors, health departments and hospitals are finding innovative ways to cope, but still lack what experts say they need to track and contain outbreaks.
articles.abstract: In both red and blue states, governors, health departments and hospitals are finding innovative ways to cope, but still lack what experts say they need to track and contain outbreaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About a week after the first report of a Covid-19 case at a meatpacking plant in southwest Kansas in early April, the state’s governor, Laura Kelly, issued a pointed warning to President Trump: Without test kits to separate the well from the sick, a fast-moving outbreak could idle facilities that produce roughly one-quarter of the nation’s meat supply.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Farah Stockman and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: As States Push to Reopen, Business Leaders Say Not So Fast
articles.snippet: “Shutting down was hard, but opening up is going to be harder,” one C.E.O. said of balancing public health and a damaged economy.
articles.abstract: “Shutting down was hard, but opening up is going to be harder,” one C.E.O. said of balancing public health and a damaged economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies in a handful of states have begun taking tentative steps to reopen stores, offices and factories that were closed by the coronavirus. Yet as the first employees and customers return, interviews with roughly 30 major employers show that businesses are confronting deep uncertainty, and many say it is simply too soon to come back.
articles.byline: By David Gelles, Kate Kelly and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: How Las Vegas Became Ground Zero for the American Jobs Crisis
articles.snippet: As the U.S. economy has shut down, the burden is falling hardest on those least prepared to handle it.
articles.abstract: As the U.S. economy has shut down, the burden is falling hardest on those least prepared to handle it.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Valicia Anderson starts to count the people she knows in Las Vegas who have lost their jobs, she runs out of fingers fast.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Trump’s Disinfectant Remark Raises a Question About the ‘Very Stable Genius’
articles.snippet: The president has often said he is exceptionally smart. His recent suggestion about injecting disinfectants was not.
articles.abstract: The president has often said he is exceptionally smart. His recent suggestion about injecting disinfectants was not.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s self-assessment has been consistent.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Small-Business Loan Program, Chaotic From Start, Gets 2nd Round
articles.snippet: The Paycheck Protection Program distributed $349 billion in less than two weeks, but lenders and borrowers confronted confusion at every step.
articles.abstract: The Paycheck Protection Program distributed $349 billion in less than two weeks, but lenders and borrowers confronted confusion at every step.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day before the federal government’s $349 billion aid program for small businesses was set to go live, the chief executive of a Minnesota bank was frantically dialing officials in Washington. Grand Rapids State Bank needed more time to understand the program, said the executive, Noah W. Wilcox, even as it faced a crush of borrowers. His pleas went unheeded.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley, Alan Rappeport and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: Large, Troubled Companies Got Bailout Money in Small-Business Loan Program
articles.snippet: Companies with accounting problems or in trouble with the government received millions in federal loans.
articles.abstract: Companies with accounting problems or in trouble with the government received millions in federal loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: A company in Georgia paid $6.5 million to resolve a Justice Department investigation — and, two weeks later, received a $10 million federally backed loan to help it survive the coronavirus crisis.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, David Enrich, Jesse Drucker and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Anna Wintour Made Condé Nast the Embodiment of Boomer Excess. Can It Change to Meet This Crisis?
articles.snippet: The theatrical flourishes and lavish lifestyles of the great media figures of a generation seem ill suited to the moment.
articles.abstract: The theatrical flourishes and lavish lifestyles of the great media figures of a generation seem ill suited to the moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus chased the fashion industry across Europe in February, from fashion week in Milan to fashion week in Paris, where designers handed out masks and some nervous fashion editors left early.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: After Closing for the Virus, Is Michelin Moving Too Quickly?
articles.snippet: The tire maker’s C.E.O. says the company must be ready for the end of quarantine, but French unions are wary.
articles.abstract: The tire maker’s C.E.O. says the company must be ready for the end of quarantine, but French unions are wary.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a recent weekday, while France was still under one of Europe’s tightest lockdowns, mammoth six-foot tractor tires were rolling off the assembly line at a Michelin factory in northeast France. Farther south, other Michelin plants turned out tires for ambulances and fire trucks as fast as small skeleton crews could make them.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Start-Ups Pursue ‘Free Money’ With Relief Funds, Prompting Backlash
articles.snippet: Some young companies have turned to the government loans not for day-to-day survival but simply to buy useful time.
articles.abstract: Some young companies have turned to the government loans not for day-to-day survival but simply to buy useful time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Domio, a start-up that offers short-term rentals, has its headquarters in a New York City loft that features beer on tap, a game room and a wall of house slippers for visitors. The fast-growing and unprofitable company has raised $117 million in venture capital, including $100 million in August.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and David McCabe

articles.headline: Europe’s Privacy Law Hasn’t Shown Its Teeth, Frustrating Advocates
articles.snippet: Nearly two years in, there has been little enforcement of the General Data Protection Regulation, once seen as ushering in a new era.
articles.abstract: Nearly two years in, there has been little enforcement of the General Data Protection Regulation, once seen as ushering in a new era.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Europe enacted the world’s toughest online privacy law nearly two years ago, it was heralded as a model to crack down on the invasive, data-hungry practices of the world’s largest technology companies.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano

articles.headline: Sympathy Cards Are Selling Out
articles.snippet: “It seems just about everyone knows someone who has died,” one maker said, helping to explain why the cards are now hard to find at many stores.
articles.abstract: “It seems just about everyone knows someone who has died,” one maker said, helping to explain why the cards are now hard to find at many stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has left retailers scrambling to meet a crushing demand for everything from milk to toilet paper to flour and yeast.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari
